verses.text: I will exalt You, my God and King, and I will bless Your name forever and ever.
verses.comment: This verse opens with personal praise directly to God as King. The perpetual nature of worship ('forever and ever') reflects both spiritual and eschatological realities, anticipating eternal worship in union with God.

verses.text: Every day I will bless You and praise Your name forever and ever.
verses.comment: The emphasis on daily praise demonstrates the call for consistent, habitual worship—an idea foundational to liturgical Christian practice. Daily prayer reflects the spiritual discipline recommended throughout Scripture.

verses.text: Great is the LORD and greatly to be praised; His greatness is beyond understanding.
verses.comment: The Psalmist’s declaration highlights the infinite nature of God. The mystery of God's greatness is a theme echoed in later Christian teaching about the incomprehensibility of God.

verses.text: One generation will declare Your works to the next and proclaim Your mighty acts.
verses.comment: Passing on knowledge of God's deeds affirms the importance of tradition in faith, where generations are charged to teach the faith and works of God—forming a spiritual lineage.

verses.text: I will meditate on the glorious majesty of Your splendor and on Your wonderful works.
verses.comment: The Psalmist encourages contemplation—a practice rooted in spiritual tradition. Meditating on God’s majesty and works fosters deeper communion and reverence for the divine.

verses.text: They will speak of the power of Your fearful deeds, and I will declare Your greatness.
verses.comment: There is communal and individual declaration of God’s powerful acts. This dual witness brings the believer into deeper participation with the worshiping community.

verses.text: They will pour forth the memory of Your abundant goodness, and will sing with joy about Your righteousness.
verses.comment: Remembrance and joyful song affirm both the celebration and solemnity present in biblical worship, echoing themes of God’s justice and mercy.

verses.text: The LORD is gracious and merciful, slow to anger and abounding in steadfast love.
verses.comment: This verse alludes to God's self-revelation to Moses. The traits described here—grace, mercy, patience, and love—form the core attributes that Christ embodies and perfects.

verses.text: The LORD is good to everyone, and His compassion is over all He has made.
verses.comment: God’s universal goodness points to a creation-wide outreach. The notion of grace extended to all anticipates the fullness of salvation revealed in Christ (cf. John 3:16).

verses.text: All Your works will give thanks to You, LORD, and Your saints will bless You.
verses.comment: The worship of both creation and the faithful community is joined together here, hinting at the communion of saints and the mystical unity of the body of Christ.

verses.text: They will speak of the glory of Your kingdom and tell of Your power.
verses.comment: The theme of God's kingdom points ahead to Christ’s proclamation of the kingdom and its manifestation in the life of the Church.

verses.text: To make known to the children of mankind Your mighty acts, and the glorious majesty of Your kingdom.
verses.comment: This verse accentuates the evangelical mandate, extending God’s revelation to all peoples and generations—akin to the Church’s mission in the world.

verses.text: Your kingdom is an everlasting kingdom, and Your dominion endures through all generations. The LORD is faithful in all His words and kind in all His works.
verses.comment: Everlasting kingship and enduring dominion prefigure the eternal kingdom established by Christ. God’s faithfulness and kindness foreshadow His covenant fulfillment in Jesus.

verses.text: The LORD upholds all who fall and lifts up all who are bowed down.
verses.comment: God’s restoration of the fallen echoes His mercy for repentant sinners, later fully revealed in the sacrificial ministry of Christ.

verses.text: The eyes of all look to You, and You give them their food at the proper time.
verses.comment: God’s providence is center-stage: He sustains all creation. This anticipates the spiritual nourishment offered in Christ, especially in the context of the Eucharist (see John 6:50-51).

verses.text: You open Your hand and satisfy the desire of every living thing.
verses.comment: This image of God’s open hand recalls generosity and nurturing care, later spiritually fulfilled through Christ’s own self-giving.

verses.text: The LORD is righteous in all His ways and kind in all His works.
verses.comment: God’s perfect righteousness points toward Christ’s sinlessness and His call for believers to receive divine goodness, reinforcing the spiritual call to holiness.

verses.text: The LORD is near to all who call on Him, to all who call on Him in truth.
verses.comment: Proximity to God through sincere prayer brings both comfort and responsibility; true worship is not empty ritual but heartfelt communion, visible in the sacramental life of the Church.

verses.text: He fulfills the desires of those who fear Him; He hears their cry and saves them.
verses.comment: God’s blessing upon those who fear Him is reaffirmed in Jesus’ teaching about prayer and reverence before the Father (cf. Matt. 7:7-11).

verses.text: The LORD preserves all who love Him, but all the wicked He will destroy.
verses.comment: The contrast between the fate of the righteous and the wicked emphasizes divine justice, a consistent biblical motif fulfilled in final judgment through Christ.

verses.text: My mouth will speak the praise of the LORD, and let all flesh bless His holy name forever and ever.
verses.comment: The Psalm ends with universal worship—a vision fulfilled in the worship offered by all creation, both now and in eternity. This unending praise is reflected in the perpetual prayers and hymns of the Church.
